source.citation: Tolan, A. & Visser, R. 2015. The effect of the number of log sorts on mechanized log processing productivity and value recovery. International Journal of Forest Engineering 26(1):36-47.
source.document_path: notes/reference/The effect of the number of log sorts on mechanized log processing productivity and value recovery.pdf
notes: Study instrumented two radiata pine cable-yarder landings (Madill 124 swing yarder & Madill 171 tower) processing 2.1–2.4 m³ stems with Cat 330DL + Waratah HTH626 processors.
Cut plans with 5, 9, 12, and 15 log sorts were uploaded via TimberRite/StanForD to test productivity and value impacts across piece-size classes (1.0–3.0 m³).

assumptions: Piece-size classes represent average stem volumes (1.0–3.0 m³) typical of coastal NZ radiata pine.
Value per PMH figures assume a reference piece size of 2.0 m³ and market pricing from the 2014 study period.
Productivity numbers exclude delay adjustments beyond those inherent in the study (processors clearing hauler chutes, balancing hot vs. cold decks).
